html_content:
1. En Afrique, il est souvent difficile de compter les morts

    Officiellement, l’ensemble des 54 pays d’Afrique comptabilisent moins de décès dûs à la Covid-19 qu'en France. Mais est-ce que, pour autant, le virus y fait moins de victimes?

    By Ruth Maclean

    Read in English

    Jan. 4, 2021

  2. 100 Civilians Are Reported Dead After Attacks in Niger

    Gunmen were described as having singled out men and boys in two villages in a region under siege by militants.

    By Omar Hama Saley and Ruth Maclean

    Jan. 3, 2021

  3. A Continent Where the Dead Are Not Counted

    All 54 African countries put together have registered fewer Covid deaths than France. That doesn’t mean people aren’t dying from the virus.

    By Ruth Maclean

    Lire en français

    Jan. 2, 2021

  4. The Problem With Problem Sharks

    A marine biologist’s ideas for singling out sharks that attack humans have prompted objections from other shark scientists.

    By Jason Nark

    Jan. 1, 2021

  5. Arrest of Cameraman in Ethiopia Signals Wider Crackdown

    The government of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has stepped up the arrests of journalists since going to war in the country’s northern region of Tigray.

    By Mady Camara and Ruth Maclean

    Dec. 29, 2020

  6. The World’s Dispatches

    In 2020, We Were There: The Year’s 13 Most Popular Dispatches

    Even challenged by extraordinary travel restrictions, our correspondents explored the world’s most compelling places, in 49 countries, although their journeys often became more local, and personal.

    By Bryant Rousseau

    阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版

    Dec. 29, 2020

  7. behind the curve

    For Covid-19 Vaccines, Some Are Too Rich — and Too Poor

    Global inequality is shaping which countries get vaccines first. In South Africa, people’s best chance for vaccines anytime soon is to join an experimental trial.

    By Matt Apuzzo, Selam Gebrekidan and Joao Silva

    Dec. 28, 2020

  8. The World Through a Lens

    Revisiting the Unseen Corners of the World

    During a year with limited travel possibilities, our World Through a Lens series offered Times readers a weekly escape. Here are some of the highlights.

    By The New York Times

    Dec. 28, 2020

  9. Refugees Come Under Fire as Old Foes Fight in Concert in Ethiopia

    Forces from neighboring Eritrea have joined the war in northern Ethiopia, and have rampaged through refugee camps committing human rights violations, officials and witnesses say.

    By Declan Walsh and Simon Marks

    Dec. 28, 2020

  10. As Virus Resurges in Africa, Doctors Fear the Worst Is Yet to Come

    The coronavirus killed far fewer people in Africa than in Europe and the Americas, leading to a widespread perception that it was a disease of the West. Now, a tide of new cases on the continent is raising alarms.

    By Sheri Fink

    Dec. 26, 2020

  11. Trilobites

    A New Population of Blue Whales Was Discovered Hiding in the Indian Ocean

    The whales in the group seem to sing a unique song.

    By Katherine J. Wu

    Dec. 23, 2020

  12. The Lives They Lived

    Mike Hoare Was a Soldier for Hire Who Led a Spectacularly Failed Coup

    Mad Mike was already in his 60s when he tried to overthrow the Marxist president of the Seychelles.

    By Sam Dolnick

    Dec. 23, 2020

  13. Police Took Their Son Away. Then the Merchants of Hope Showed Up.

    The police seize and kill young men in Nigeria. Then pastors, lawyers and so-called human rights advocates squeeze money out of their families, promising to help find them.

    By Ruth Maclean and Ben Ezeamalu

    Dec. 23, 2020

  14. Navy Warship’s Secret Mission Off West Africa Aims to Help Punish Venezuela

    The tale of the cruiser San Jacinto underscores the Trump administration’s animus toward Venezuela and how the postelection purge of top Pentagon leaders is roiling the military.

    By Eric Schmitt and Julie Turkewitz

    Leer en español

    Dec. 22, 2020

    15. Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

  15. 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombing Victims Are Assured Equal Compensation in Deal With Sudan

    A new congressional agreement largely puts to rest months of furious negotiations over how to help Sudan’s fragile transitional government, which faces lawsuits accusing the country of harboring Al Qaeda.

    By Lara Jakes

    Dec. 21, 2020

  16. U.S. Unseals Charges Against New Suspect in 1988 Lockerbie Bombing

    Attorney General William P. Barr said that investigators had obtained a confession in 2012 from a bomb expert admitting his role in the terrorist attack on a jetliner over Scotland.

    By Adam Goldman and Katie Benner

    Dec. 21, 2020

  17. Trump Incentives for Signing Peace Accords With Israel Could Be at Risk

    Diplomatic sweeteners for joining the Abraham Accords that were offered to Morocco, Sudan and the United Arab Emirates could be rejected by Congress or reversed by the incoming Biden administration.

    By Lara Jakes

    Dec. 20, 2020

  18. ‘I Miss Home’: In Tigray Conflict, Displaced Children Suffer

    Of the thousands of refugees who have fled the conflict in the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray, nearly a third are children. Hundreds of them walked unaccompanied to Sudan.

    By Abdi Latif Dahir and Tyler Hicks

    Dec. 20, 2020

  19. TimesVideo

    Nigerian Schoolboys Released from Kidnappers

    President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria said on Friday the country’s government would “keep on trying” to secure the country for all of its citizens after hundreds of boys kidnapped last week from their school were freed on Thursday night following six days in captivity.

    By The Associated Press and Reuters

    Dec. 18, 2020

  20. Freed, but Not Yet Home: Nigeria’s Abducted Schoolboys Meet President

    Capitalizing on a rare victory, the Nigerian government publicly displayed the more than 300 boys who had been released, and insisted it had not paid ransom.

    By Ruth Maclean and Ismail Alfa

    Dec. 18, 2020
